awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Factors Driving Changes within Global Healthcare Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
Though by no means a new phenomenon, medical travel - the seeking of healthcare services abroad - continues to grow rapidly as individuals look to the global market to meet their healthcare needs. While anthropologists have pointed to the intensely varied nature of medical travel experiences, there remains much to be understood about the different kinds of healthcare concerns which drive medical travel, as well as how individuals and families navigate financial, bureaucratic, and other systems to obtain care abroad. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirically-grounded, scientific research, seeks to understand how individuals' and families' desires for particular healthcare treatments (e.g. cancer screenings and treatments) may influence their temporary or long-term migrations to the U.S. and elsewhere, as well as how their shifting healthcare concerns may evidence changing ideas regarding illness, health, and expectations of healthcare systems. Understanding these factors is imperative to informing programs and policies that respond to the shifting nature of contemporary, global healthcare seeking, particularly as it impacts migrations to and the use of healthcare services in the U.S. and elsewhere. 

Zakea Boeger, under the supervision of Dr. Jan Brunson of the University of Hawai'i at Manoa, will examine the factors impacting travel to service healthcare needs. This yearlong research project will be conducted in Nuku'alofa, Kingdom of Tonga, where the researcher has conducted previous work. As the Tongan government supports a publically funded healthcare system, Nuku'alofa is an apt site for identifying key healthcare concerns that drive individuals to seek healthcare abroad, and to draw on often-limited resources to do so. Scientific research of medical travel has tended to focus on populations with more extensive resources to finance travel for medical purposes, so this site offers an opportunity to test a number of prevailing assumptions about the drivers of medical travel. The researcher will engage in extensive interviews with individuals and families who have engaged in and/or plan to engage in medical travel, so as to gain an understanding of the motivations for and means by which individuals are able to access health care abroad. Interviews will provide insight into the possible relationship between Tongans' primary medical travel destinations (e.g. the U.S.) and contemporary, ongoing Tongan and Pacific migration to the U.S. and elsewhere. Interviews will also consider how medical travel experiences may be intertwined with shifting socio-cultural notions of health, appropriate health care, and resultant expectations of healthcare systems in Tonga and abroad. Project findings will help illuminate broader health concerns that drive global, medical travel, as well as how this travel may impact healthcare systems in the U.S. and abroad.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the experiences of Tongan medical travelers, or Tongans who travel from the Kingdom of Tonga to Australia, New Zealand, and the US to access medical care unavailable locally. In focusing on those with low financial capital, this project considered how Tongans might utilize alternative forms of capital to access overseas care, as well as how the seeking of such care might indicate shifting social and cultural understandings of (bio)medicine, health, and illness.

           This research resulted in three major findings. First, all treatments sought by travelers were for non-communicable diseases (NCDs) or related complications, including chemo and radiotherapy for various cancers, heart surgery for congenital and non-congenital illnesses, and kidney dialysis. Though the US was a highly sought after destination, the close proximity of Australia and New Zealand—entailing cheaper flights, shorter travel during emergencies, and access to large family networks—made them more popular destinations. Second, Tongan medical travel would be virtually impossible without extensive overseas networks. Not only did overseas family members and friends provide accommodation and financial support, they helped nurse travelers, cook favorite foods, and plan fun outings and other activities that gave travelers invaluable mental, spiritual, and emotional support. Third, relatively major shifts in ideas about health and illness occurred during travel. For example, travelers discussed changes in attitude regarding diseases like cancer, explaining that, in Tonga, cancer was a death sentence, but, once overseas, they were treated like “regular” sick persons by doctors, inserting a narrative of hope into their treatments and thereby prompting them both to re-think the healing potentials of (bio)medical care, and to recommend that others do whatever necessary to get overseas care. Furthermore, families’ willingness to shift limited resources to travelers may suggest that (bio)medical care has been folded into existing social structures of obligation and (self) care.

            As this project focuses on Tongans seeking life-saving treatments abroad, it will contribute to the growing body of scholarship in medical anthropology that seeks to move beyond medical tourism and draw attention to the highly varied experiences of global medical travelers. In doing so, this project will bring specific attention to the essential role of global family networks in supporting medical travel and overseas treatment. Furthermore, as this project revealed how biomedical practice and ideas may become incorporated into—rather than displacing—local structures of family, (self) care, and resource management, it will contribute to medical anthropology discussions and understandings of how biomedicine can be subject to specific processes of localization, rather than acting as a monolithic force worldwide.

            This project also stands to make a contribution to critical global health studies. In highlighting Tongans’ agency as they work to decide upon, pursue, and successfully access overseas health care, this research will further arguments that challenge and disrupt the victimizing, often infantilizing portrayals of the Global South that are common in development literature. Furthermore, and insofar as this project suggests that Tongans’ diasporic networks serve as an alternative form of capital and a means to access global resources, this project also stands to make a contribution to diaspora and mobility studies, and especially to discussions regarding network capital—who has access to it, how it functions, and how it might be used to crosscut stratifications of class, etc.—and its global roles. Finally, as transnationalism and diasporic flows draw increasing focus within Pacific studies, this project will add to these conversations by providing insight into the relationships between health and migration more specifically, including how ideas about health and health care both shape and are shaped by these flows, contributing to desires to migrate, expectations of local health care facilities, and ideas about disease, life expectancy, and what makes a person “healthy.”

            At present, both medical travel and NCDs seem only to be on the rise, both worldwide and within the Pacific. Given the regularity with which Pacific medical travel occurs, this project may impact health policy and practice in the US, Tonga, and the wider Pacific, especially as it revealed some of the struggles that Tongan (and likely other Pacific Islander and global) medical travelers face before, during, and after travel. This included misinformation regarding what treatments will be like, difficulties obtaining travel documents, struggles to access medicines and follow-up once home, and, for those with chronic conditions, sometimes getting “stuck” in the US and other destinations in a nexus of medical need, bureaucracy, and mounting debt. Future travelers may also find these results helpful—as they may help guide travelers’ plans, or make such travel seem more “doable”—and perhaps even inspiring, given the rich stories of how overseas networks function not only as resources, but also as networks of hope and care.
